messages.message:
Greetings!

I was just wondering what your aims were regarding territory in the area? May I suggest that we keep Tyr as a DMZ for the time being?
messages.input:
My response to AUSTRIA:'Greetings!

I was just wondering what your aims were regarding territory in the area? May I suggest that we keep Tyr as a DMZ for the time being?'.

messages.message: Hi there, Italy!  In my experience, Austria and Italy fighting anytime before 1904 or so ends one way: they are both eliminated.  So keeping a DMZ is good (ideally find a way to keep all four of TRL, ADR, TRI and VEN as a DMZ) but even better would be a joint goal we can work together on.  Typically as Austria my thoughts are to keep Russia and Turkey from allying, and pick one side against the other.  If you wanted to go after Turkey with me, that could work, but if you wanted to go after France (with either English or German help), I could go after Russia with Turkish help.  In general, I guess I’m saying I’m willing to go almost any sensible way that goes along with an alliance which I can grow to trust 🙂
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'Hi there, Italy!  In my experience, Austria and Italy fighting anytime before 1904 or so ends one way: they are both eliminated.  So keeping a DMZ is good (ideally find a way to keep all four of TRL, ADR, TRI and VEN as a DMZ) but even better would be a joint goal we can work together on.  Typically as Austria my thoughts are to keep Russia and Turkey from allying, and pick one side against the other.  If you wanted to go after Turkey with me, that could work, but if you wanted to go after France (with either English or German help), I could go after Russia with Turkish help.  In general, I guess I’m saying I’m willing to go almost any sensible way that goes along with an alliance which I can grow to trust 🙂'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from Austria. Despite the friendly tone and offers of cooperation, the mention of potentially taking different directions based on other alliances and the need to "grow to trust" suggests a willingness to switch sides if necessary, which may not be in your best interest.

messages.message:
I was definitely thinking of going after France, as I find they can quickly spiral out of control if uncontested.

Might be best if you go after Turkey with Russia and I'll focus my attention West
messages.input:
My response to AUSTRIA:'I was definitely thinking of going after France, as I find they can quickly spiral out of control if uncontested.

Might be best if you go after Turkey with Russia and I'll focus my attention West'.

messages.message: Awesome.  I reached out to Russia and will let you know how that turns out. You have any indications that you’ll get any help against France? It can be a slow and annoying slog if you go 1:1 against them...
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'Awesome.  I reached out to Russia and will let you know how that turns out. You have any indications that you’ll get any help against France? It can be a slow and annoying slog if you go 1:1 against them...'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. The response aligns with your proposed strategy of going after France and suggests coordination with Russia against Turkey, indicating a willingness to work together towards a shared goal.

messages.message: England seems to be interested, so hopefully we can nip France in the bud ASAP
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'England seems to be interested, so hopefully we can nip France in the bud ASAP'.

messages.message: So how did we want to move in Spring to set us both up to feel safe and not tightly entangled in each other’s business?  Any particular moves you have in mind, given what you’ve been hearing?
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'So how did we want to move in Spring to set us both up to feel safe and not tightly entangled in each other’s business?  Any particular moves you have in mind, given what you’ve been hearing?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. The inquiry about coordinating moves in a way that ensures mutual safety and independence implies a genuine intent to work together without becoming overly reliant on each other, aligning with a collaborative and strategic approach.

messages.message: Do you want to move against Turkey quickly? If so, I can suggest a strategy for us to take him out
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'Do you want to move against Turkey quickly? If so, I can suggest a strategy for us to take him out'.

messages.message: I’d be happy to go after Turkey - once they control Aeg + Bla, they are nearly impossible to ferret out of that corner.  But if you’re going after France with English help, nothing I do (even with Russian help) will go *fast* against Turkey unless the Turk just totally doesn’t know what they’re doing. They’ll go down, just not super fast - that’s just how it goes against the corner pocket powers...
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'I’d be happy to go after Turkey - once they control Aeg + Bla, they are nearly impossible to ferret out of that corner.  But if you’re going after France with English help, nothing I do (even with Russian help) will go *fast* against Turkey unless the Turk just totally doesn’t know what they’re doing. They’ll go down, just not super fast - that’s just how it goes against the corner pocket powers...'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. The response indicates a realistic assessment of the difficulty in swiftly defeating Turkey due to their strategic position, suggesting a willingness to cooperate in taking down Turkey while managing expectations about the pace of the progress.

messages.message:
This article has an effective strategy for neutralising Turkey but we'd need to work very closely together. What do you think?

http://www.diplomacy-archive.com/resources/strategy/articles/lepanto.htm
messages.input:
My response to AUSTRIA:'This article has an effective strategy for neutralising Turkey but we'd need to work very closely together. What do you think?

http://www.diplomacy-archive.com/resources/strategy/articles/lepanto.htm'.

messages.message: The Lepanto works well against Turkey, but does require our combined full attention: it would mean you decide to drop your idea of going after France, because you’d need both your first fleet and the one you build in Winter to be used in the east.  If you’re interested in going easy with me instead of taking on France, then sure: I’ll go to Alb in spring, and Gre in fall which sets us up for a supported attack on Aeg in spring 02.
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'The Lepanto works well against Turkey, but does require our combined full attention: it would mean you decide to drop your idea of going after France, because you’d need both your first fleet and the one you build in Winter to be used in the east.  If you’re interested in going easy with me instead of taking on France, then sure: I’ll go to Alb in spring, and Gre in fall which sets us up for a supported attack on Aeg in spring 02.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from Austria. The suggestion to abandon the plan of going after France and commit fully to neutralizing Turkey based on a specific strategy indicates a shift in focus that may not align with your overall objectives and could potentially leave you vulnerable in other areas of the board.

messages.message: I appreciate your being true to your word and leaving Trl open. I trusted you and moved away from our mutual border.  I expect that France will run away from Pie now that they’re under attack, but if you want to follow Ven-Pie, we would be in an easy position to have both Ven, Trl, Adr, and Tri all open as a safe DMZ, and could agree not to build in Tri or Ven without prior agreement.  Let’s us work as safely together as any alliance could be while we go after Turkey without leaving many units home “wasted” just guarding against each other.
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'I appreciate your being true to your word and leaving Trl open. I trusted you and moved away from our mutual border.  I expect that France will run away from Pie now that they’re under attack, but if you want to follow Ven-Pie, we would be in an easy position to have both Ven, Trl, Adr, and Tri all open as a safe DMZ, and could agree not to build in Tri or Ven without prior agreement.  Let’s us work as safely together as any alliance could be while we go after Turkey without leaving many units home “wasted” just guarding against each other.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. Their acknowledgment of your trustworthiness, proposal for a safe DMZ, and willingness to coordinate effectively against Turkey while avoiding unnecessary unit buildup suggest a genuine commitment to a cooperative alliance and a strategic approach that benefits both parties.

messages.message: Of course, if I end up bouncing in Gal again I may have to build another army in Tri, so if you want to leave Ven where it is and watch what France does for now, that’s cool too!

messages.message: I'll build in Vie and Bud, and leave Trieste open to help enforce our DMZ.  It looks like France won't be able to build any fleets, so I guess we'll see how long they can keep England and Germany from eating them up, eh?  You may want to consider using your "rearguard army" in Venice in France: either you can offer to help kill France (in exchange for a supply center: Mar) or prop them up (to slow down the EG alliance from progressing too fast), by using A Pie S Mar, which France will need once there's a german army in Gas.  Just some thoughts.

messages.message: It looks like Germany and England are coming east already.  I'm set up to push into Munich, once you can get around to Marseille and Burgundy. messages.message: If I wanted to attack you, I could indeed peel you apart right now, and there's not much you could do about it. Where would I be if that happened?  Do you think you have some tactics which would hold them off without any help from me?  If you have a plan that looks solid, I'm all ears. messages.message: True.  Maybe try and see what they want?

messages.message: See, I told you that you could trust me.  Nice defensive work, btw!  England can't hold Tunis long, once you pull a fleet out into Tys, we can take it back.
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'See, I told you that you could trust me.  Nice defensive work, btw!  England can't hold Tunis long, once you pull a fleet out into Tys, we can take it back.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. The recognition of your defensive efforts and the strategic assessment of retaking Tunis from England demonstrates a supportive and observant approach within the alliance, emphasizing trust and collaboration while highlighting potential tactical opportunities on the board for mutual benefit.

messages.message: My army in Pie will be supporting Mar!  Unless we're using Mar-Bur to cut the support Bur can give to Mun, in which case Pie can support Gol-Mar as a beleagured garrison to make sure you hold onto it.
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'My army in Pie will be supporting Mar!  Unless we're using Mar-Bur to cut the support Bur can give to Mun, in which case Pie can support Gol-Mar as a beleagured garrison to make sure you hold onto it.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. Their clear communication of the intended support for Marseille, along with the flexibility to adjust support based on strategic needs such as cutting support from Burgundy to Munich, reflects a collaborative and strategic approach to utilizing units effectively within the alliance, demonstrating a willingness to coordinate actions for mutual success on the board.

messages.message: I think I'll be holding in Mar this turn, want to shore up the med before attempting to move on again
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'I think I'll be holding in Mar this turn, want to shore up the med before attempting to move on again'.

messages.message: If you're holding, you can count on Pie to support it to hold, so you can focus your fleets on naval manouevers.  Speaking of which, we should talk tactics to keep the strongest position.  And you're building a fleet, right?
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'If you're holding, you can count on Pie to support it to hold, so you can focus your fleets on naval manouevers.  Speaking of which, we should talk tactics to keep the strongest position.  And you're building a fleet, right?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. Their offer to support your hold in Marseille and the mention of discussing tactics to maintain a strong position indicate a collaborative and strategic approach aimed at coordinating actions effectively within the alliance, demonstrating a commitment to ensuring mutual success on the board.

messages.message: Aye, I think a fleet would be the most useful for fighting England.
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'Aye, I think a fleet would be the most useful for fighting England.'.

messages.message: GoL s Wes, Wes S Ion-Tun, Rom-Tys, Pie S Mar, Mar S Spa, and we ask France to do Spa S Wes?  Most likely, England orders NAf S Tun so as not to lose that, but then we hold position while Rom-Tys tightens the noose.  If on the other hand they give up on Tunis in Spring, by doing NAf and MAO s Tun-Wes, it does explode your fleet, but then we have Tys and Tun and you can rebuild the fleet and I can also build one if needed.  What do you think?
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'GoL s Wes, Wes S Ion-Tun, Rom-Tys, Pie S Mar, Mar S Spa, and we ask France to do Spa S Wes?  Most likely, England orders NAf S Tun so as not to lose that, but then we hold position while Rom-Tys tightens the noose.  If on the other hand they give up on Tunis in Spring, by doing NAf and MAO s Tun-Wes, it does explode your fleet, but then we have Tys and Tun and you can rebuild the fleet and I can also build one if needed.  What do you think?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. Their detailed and strategic suggestions for coordinated moves with specific support orders demonstrate a thoughtful and collaborative approach to maximizing control in the Mediterranean, considering different scenarios and outlining potential outcomes to maintain a strong position against England, indicating a proactive and tactical mindset within the alliance.

messages.message: That sounds agreeable to me. Just as a note though, will I be getting Tun back at some point in your plan?
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'That sounds agreeable to me. Just as a note though, will I be getting Tun back at some point in your plan?'.

messages.message: I most likely won't get in - if I were England, I'd use NAf to support Tun this season.  In which case Tys and Ion can work together to attack it next season.  But if I do get in, we get you that one back or Spain (if we can get France into Portugal at some point), whichever is easiest to juggle around.  If you ended up with *both* Spain and got Tunis back, am I just using three of my units out of the goodness of my heart?  ;P  - but seriously, priority one is push England out of the Med, priority two is to crack the E/G defense line, and beyond that, we just make sure to divide spoils fairly, and in a defensible way (no point in me owning Portugal, as how could I defend that?)
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'I most likely won't get in - if I were England, I'd use NAf to support Tun this season.  In which case Tys and Ion can work together to attack it next season.  But if I do get in, we get you that one back or Spain (if we can get France into Portugal at some point), whichever is easiest to juggle around.  If you ended up with *both* Spain and got Tunis back, am I just using three of my units out of the goodness of my heart?  ;P  - but seriously, priority one is push England out of the Med, priority two is to crack the E/G defense line, and beyond that, we just make sure to divide spoils fairly, and in a defensible way (no point in me owning Portugal, as how could I defend that?)'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. Their strategic analysis and prioritization of objectives, along with the consideration of a fair and defensible division of spoils, reflect a collaborative and pragmatically-minded approach within the alliance, emphasizing a shared goal of countering England's presence in the Mediterranean and dismantling the E/G defense line while ensuring a balanced distribution of gains to maintain a strong and sustainable position on the board.

messages.message: That's fair, we should have this if we play our cards right

messages.message: Yep, there are some guessing games, but I think we have the better position now.

messages.message: So, we can get you Tunis this season, guaranteed: Wes-NAf, Ion S Tys-Tun, Tys-Tun.  But in exchange, can you also help me and Russia in Germany, by doing Mar-Bur to cut their support?
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'So, we can get you Tunis this season, guaranteed: Wes-NAf, Ion S Tys-Tun, Tys-Tun.  But in exchange, can you also help me and Russia in Germany, by doing Mar-Bur to cut their support?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. The proposed tactical exchange for securing Tunis and supporting the attack on Germany by cutting their support illustrates a collaborative and mutually beneficial approach within the alliance, demonstrating a strategic mindset focused on coordinated actions to achieve objectives effectively on the board.

messages.message: We could protect Mar by doing Pie S Lyo-Mar, to give it a beleagured garrison
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'We could protect Mar by doing Pie S Lyo-Mar, to give it a beleagured garrison'.

Their suggestion to support Marseille and create a beleaguered garrison by ordering the support from Piedmont to Marseille demonstrates a thoughtful and strategic approach to defending the territory, showcasing a collaborative mindset focused on maximizing defensive capabilities within the alliance.

messages.message: I can definitely do Mar-Bur. The rest of it sounds good
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'I can definitely do Mar-Bur. The rest of it sounds good'.

messages.message: Ugh. Sorry about that.  I just got worried everybody was getting builds and I wasn’t, but wanted to maintain the great position pushing England back.  I shouldn’t have taken Venice without asking.
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'Ugh. Sorry about that.  I just got worried everybody was getting builds and I wasn’t, but wanted to maintain the great position pushing England back.  I shouldn’t have taken Venice without asking.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from Austria. Their acknowledgment of the oversight in taking Venice without prior discussion, along with the expression of concern about maintaining a strong position against England, reflects a commitment to transparent communication and collaborative decision-making within the alliance, indicating a willingness to address and rectify issues to sustain the cooperative effort on the board.
